name: TPCS 20TH-C AMERICAN LIT: CRIME & AMERICAN FICTION

section.name: TPCS 20TH-C AMERICAN LIT: CRIME & AMERICAN FICTION

values.comments:
This course explores the complex role of crime in 20th century American fiction and addresses a variety of topics and questions including the aesthetics and politics of crime, the relationship between representations of crime and crime in reality, the social, moral, and ethical dimensions of crime, and more. The course material looks at the genre of crime fiction and literary novels in which crime plays a central role, along with the Hollywood film noir and contemporary police procedural television shows. Readings include works by Cormac McCarthy, Truman Capote and Alice Sebold, and are supplemented with films directed by Orson Welles, David Cronenberg and Spike Lee.

Students considered ENGL 263 to be a “great” and “entertaining” course, with one calling it the “highlight” of the semester. They greatly applauded the selected material, with one student pointing to the volume of more current selected works making the course’s topics something easy to “relate to.” This was bolstered by the engaging discussion present in each lesson. One student felt that the class needed more structure, but he/she was alone in holding this sentiment – the vast majority greatly enjoyed all aspects of the course. One student proclaimed that it was “exactly what [he/she] hoped a class at a liberal arts school would be.” Another said simply, “awesome class!”

Professor Fiumara received high praise from students. Called an “approachable and engaging professor,” students felt he had a “genuine interest in the success of his students.” They lauded his ability to create an atmosphere that “made participation easy, even fun,” which lent greatly to the class discussions. But, one student felt that Professor Fiumara was perhaps “too nice,” and that he “cut everyone so much slack” out of his perceived value of in-class discussion over assigned work.

The workload was considered quite manageable, as the engaging nature of the readings and films made the material enjoyable. Students were initially asked to write two essays and a final paper, though the second essay and the final paper were eventually dropped. As mentioned, not all students were pleased with the decreased number of assignments, though this was a testament to student satisfaction with both the material and discussion.
